Letter 37

Letters to Summer is a newsletter written by two best friends living on opposite sides of the country. Every other Thursday, we share the things we're reading, watching, listening to, and enjoying. We hope you like it.

COVID-19 Relief

We wanted to suggest a couple of relief funds to donate to right now, if you‚Äôre able to. COVID Bail Out is an organization helping vulnerable folks in NYC prisons, and @Oaklandworkersfund is taking donations for service workers in Oakland on Venmo. (P.S. if there are any specific relief funds you‚Äôd like us to highlight in a future letter, email us and let us know!)

On nostalgia

I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm bored, or because I‚Äôm desperately searching for new coping mechanisms in the middle of all of this, but I‚Äôve been spending a lot of time thinking about a reaching for experiences I had growing up. Last night, after a couple glasses of wine, I went down a rabbit hole searching for all the old MMORPGs I used to play. (Pixie Hollow, anyone? Virtual Magic Kingdom? Toontown? Bring them back!) I‚Äôve been heavily considering joining Summer as she rewatches Glee from the beginning. And now I guess Stephanie Meyer is publishing Midnight Sun, which, alright! Nostalgia is not always a good thing, but I‚Äôm finding it comforting these days, when little else is. It makes sense that we‚Äôd want to turn our minds to a past in which we could go outside without masks on, and enjoy the things that occupied our time when we were younger and had less to worry about‚ÄîI think it‚Äôs okay to let yourself lean into the nostalgia a little bit! Make a playlist of songs you loved in high school. Revisit your favorite movies and TV shows and books and games, even if they aren‚Äôt as good now, just to scratch the itch. And then return to the present, because there is nothing more important than paying attention to what is happening around us right now.

‚Äì Jillian

We‚Äôre 7-ish weeks into quarantine, which means I‚Äôve been rewatching a lot of TV. Nostalgia used to feel like an ugly word, a feeling I would wrinkle my nose at when I heard people talk about past eras. I now know this is because I was truly too young, and most of the nostalgia my peers had was constructed by media that told them to feel nostalgic for a time they never experienced. It felt artificial and white-washy, like why would you want to experience a time in which the world was noticeably so much worse. Revisiting things from 2009 or 2012, though, I find myself nostalgic not for the Obama era (lmao) but the way that media carried me. Mostly, I‚Äôm thinking about shows like Glee, where I can trace so much of my fandom lineage, and that I can thank for so many of my friends (like Jillian üòÄ), the way I think about media, and the way I process discourse and conflict‚Äîmy patience was never tested more than hiatus weeks, but the absolute content those breaks generated. Unparalleled. I wasn‚Äôt in a great place mentally back then, but I can still pull fondness when I think about my shows. Something to be excited about. Something to make you feel something. I‚Äôm trying to hold onto things to be excited about‚Äîand right now, that manifests in reliving my urgency for a new episode of Glee each week.

‚Äì Summer

We recommend

üìñ Zaina Alsous‚Äôs A Theory of Birds

I recommend a lot of poetry in this newsletter, to the point where it seems like I‚Äôve probably never read a novel, but Zaina‚Äôs collection gave me the feeling of reading a very immersive piece of fiction‚Äînot saying her work reads as prose in anyway, nor is it escapism, but there‚Äôs this incredible balance between intricacy and simplicity. Those words are not necessarily at odds, but the weight of Zaina‚Äôs work never feels overwhelming, rather gravitational. I was excited to turn each page, excited to see what else she had in store for her reader. This is a work I will revisit over and over and over again‚ÄîI read each poem twice, wanting to give them all of my time, poking at Hazem to read along with me several times so that they got the attention they deserved. It‚Äôs brilliant. It‚Äôs brilliant. Check Indiebound, Bookshop.org, or the publisher‚Äôs website to get your copy.

‚Äì Summer

‚úâÔ∏è The Creative Independent newsletter

The content that The Creative Independent puts out is always fantastic‚Äîbeautiful essays about writing and other types of creative work; interviews with artists, musicians, and creators of all sorts; and guides for just about everything (from how to write a poem to how to lose someone)‚Äîbut their daily newsletter is my favorite way to experience what they have to offer. My most recent favorite featured an interview with Jenny Odell, author of How To Do Nothing, which we have also recommended. Go read it immediately, and then subscribe.

‚Äì Jillian

üì∫ Never Have I Ever

Truly, I was hesitant to begin this show after the last few seasons of The Mindy Project, but that all faded away after the first episode. I love seeing high school shows that do away with strict caste (especially in contrast to the Glee I‚Äôve been watching) and instead focus on the realistic fluidity of relationships; familiarity is present among basically everyone, it‚Äôs easy to be friends and find common ground with pretty much anyone when you‚Äôre in the same classes. Devi is a fantastic character‚Äîridiculously funny and every mistake feels earned (again, in contrast to Glee). The side characters are precious and have stories I‚Äôm excited about, too‚Äîthey are not set-dressing, so much the opposite in fact that assuming so is an addressed conflict. The Sherman Oaks setting is used with such a wonderful specificity and I am a sucker for anything in LA suburbs. Also there are a lot of hot people! It‚Äôs on Netflix, go enjoy!

‚Äì Summer

üéÆ ACNH Travel Guide

This probably isn‚Äôt news to anyone, but I‚Äôve been playing a lot of Animal Crossing New Horizons lately. I want to give a shout-out to this super nice companion app that I‚Äôve been using that makes it easy to see which bugs and fish are in season (and available at the time you‚Äôre playing), what you‚Äôve already found and donated to the museum, what events are coming up, and tons more. It also has links to other great community resources, so you can test out new island tunes or track and predict your turnip prices without leaving the app. Download for iOS here.

‚Äì Jillian
